intro: Krameria secundiflora var. angustifolia, commonly known as the narrowleaf burro bush, is a perennial shrub native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its spiny, woody stems and clusters of small, yellowish flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant has small, narrow leaves that are typically arranged in opposite pairs along the stem. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and along dry streambeds. Krameria secundiflora var. angustifolia is adapted to withstand drought and heat, making it a hardy plant in desert ecosystems.
